com.sri.ai.grinder.rewriter.api

Interface Simplifier

  • All Superinterfaces:
    com.sri.ai.util.base.BinaryFunction<Expression,Context,Expression>, Rewriter, TopRewriter
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    And, BooleanCommutativeAssociative, CommutativeAssociative, CommutativeAssociativeWithOperationOnJavaConstantsOnly, DifferenceArithmeticSimplifier, Disequality, DistributeIntersectionOverUnionSimplifier, Division, ElementOfExtensionalSetSimplifier, ElementOfIntensionalUnionSimplifier, Equality, Equivalence, Exponentiation, ExtensionalSetEqualEmptySetSimplifier, GreaterThan, GreaterThanOrEqualTo, IfThenElse, Implication, IntensionalSetConditionSimplifier, IntensionalSetFalseConditionToEmptySetSimplifier, IntensionalSetToConditionalSimplifier, IntensionalUnionEqualToEmptySetSimplifier, IntensionalUnionIntersectionEqualToEmptySetSimplifier, IntensionalUnionToUnionsOfIntensionalSetsOfBaseTypeSimplifier, IntersectionEmptySetSimplifier, IntersectionExtensionalSetSimplifier, IntersectionIntensionalSetsSimplifier, InversionSimplifier, LessThan, LessThanOrEqualTo, LinearRealArithmeticSimplifier, Max, Minus, Not, Or, Plus, SetExpressionIsEqualToEmptySet, SetIntersectExtensionalSetEqualToEmptySetSimplifier, Times, TupleDisequalitySimplifier, TupleEqualitySimplifier, TupleGetSimplifier, TupleQuantifierSimplifier, TupleSetSimplifier, TupleValuedFreeVariablesSimplifier, UnaryMinus, UnionEmptySetSimplifier, UnionOfSetsEqualEmptySetSimplifier
    Functional Interface:
    This is a functional interface and can therefore be used as the assignment target for a lambda expression or method reference.

    @FunctionalInterface
public interface Simplifier
extends TopRewriter
    A Simplifier knows just enough about the symbols in a language to simplify it in a shallow way, that is, to replace function applications by a simpler equivalent expression, if that expression is determined by their immediate arguments. Shallow simplifications are required to take polynomial time in the size of expressions (preferably linear time).

    Examples of shallow simplifications are x + 0 to x, x or true to true, and x + 1 + 3 to x + 4. Simplifications that are not shallow include those requiring case analysis (inference), such as (p and q) or (p and not q)leading to p.

    A simplifier can be used as a rewriter that always returns unconditional steps, that is, solutions.

    Author:
    braz
